intro: Rhexia subtriplinervia, commonly known as the three-veined inkberry, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes many shrubs and flowering plants adapted to acidic soils. The plant features small, dark blue to purple flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are typically ovate with three prominent veins, giving it its scientific name. Rhexia subtriplinervia thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and wetlands.
